description.plain:
Stephen Bruner (born October 19, 1984), better known by his stage name Thundercat, is a multi-genre bass player, producer, and singer-songwriter from Los Angeles, California. He has released three solo albums and is perhaps most known for his work alongside producer Flying Lotus, as well as thrash metal band Suicidal Tendencies. He also notably appeared on Kendrick Lamar’s critically acclaimed March 2015 album, To Pimp a Butterfly, among other works.

He is the son of Ronald Bruner Sr., a drummer who has performed and recorded with Diana Ross, The Temptations, Randy Crawford, and Gladys Knight. He has two brothers: virtuoso drummer Ronald Bruner Jr. and musician/producer Jameel Bruner, a.k.a. Kintaro.

body.plain:
Stephen Bruner (born October 19, 1984), better known by his stage name Thundercat, is a multi-genre bass player, producer, and singer-songwriter from Los Angeles, California. He has released three solo albums and is perhaps most known for his work alongside producer Flying Lotus, as well as thrash metal band Suicidal Tendencies. He also notably appeared on Kendrick Lamar’s critically acclaimed March 2015 album, To Pimp a Butterfly, among other works.

He is the son of Ronald Bruner Sr., a drummer who has performed and recorded with Diana Ross, The Temptations, Randy Crawford, and Gladys Knight. He has two brothers: virtuoso drummer Ronald Bruner Jr. and musician/producer Jameel Bruner, a.k.a. Kintaro.

description.plain:
“Dragonball Durag” is a song about getting accepted by a girl no matter what it takes. Getting a new whip, flexing jewelry, and even wearing a dragonball durag.

Thundercat reveals his insecurity through the motif of “would you tell me the truth?” Even though Thundercat has his “swag turned on” with his dragonball durag, he still seeks his girl’s approval, highlighting dependence on her.

description.plain:
This song was originally performed at One Eyed Jacks in New Orleans from the Pitchfork Nightcap. A studio version was released on SoundCloud on June 19, 2015 with production by Flying Lotus for Thundercat’s album The Beyond / Where the Giants Roam.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HffP63WF4yo

The track was also later included on Thundercat’s 2017 LP, Drunk.

description.plain:
“Friend Zone” is the second single taken from Thundercat’s 2017 album, Drunk. It was released on February 14 – Valentine’s Day.

On the track, Thundercat laments being stuck in the friend zone with references to Diablo, Mortal Kombat and Kendrick Lamar.

The track was produced by Brainfeeder labelmate Mono/Poly. He previously co-produced two tracks on Thundercat’s 2015 release, The Beyond / Where the Giants Roam.

description.plain:
“Walk on By” is the third single off Thundercat’s Drunk. It was released on February 22, two days before the album.

The song features Compton-born rapper and close collaborator Kendrick Lamar. The pair collaborated previously on Kendrick’s critically-acclaimed LP To Pimp A Butterfly – Thundercat was credited as a featuring artist on “Wesley’s Theory” and single “These Walls.”

On the track, Thundercat considers the weight of loneliness whilst Kendrick shoulders the weight of the “wrongs” he’s trying to right.

description.plain:
From Thundercat’s second album Apocalypse, this song describes a crazy New Year’s party:

One of the new songs, “Oh Sheit It’s X,” is about a New Year’s party that went on for two days. I asked Thundercat if it’s a true story. “Yeah. It absolutely is. That’s a story that actually happened,” he says. Flying Lotus was out of town. “It was so epic,” says Thundercat. “And if you ask Lotus, to this day, he will still get mad.” “Oh yeah! Hell yeah I’m mad,” says Lotus. “It just sounded like the best party ever.”

Via Flying Lotus’s Twitter commentary  about “Oh Sheit It’s X”:

another thing started by @mono__poly and then we did our thing. i always loved this song.. its actually the oldest of the bunch. the first version of this song is the worst demo recording of all time and it was still dope. i was so excited to work on this.. do my thing. ‘oh shit I’m fucked up’ u don’t know what kind of battle i went thru to actually have those words come out on this album. he was like.. my mom is gonna hear that!! i said.. that would be everyones favorite part of the song. with no disrespect i heard the daft thing and was like. ohh shit.. u can take that how u will.

songs.embed_content: Read “Oh Sheit It's X” by Thundercat on Genius
songs.full_title: Oh Sheit It's X by Thundercat
songs.title: Oh Sheit It’s X

description.plain:
“Show You the Way” is the lead single from Thundercat’s 2017 album Drunk.

The track is an expression of love and light that finds him trading verses with a pair of unexpected, yet completely logical co-conspirators: yacht rock maestros Kenny Loggins and Michael McDonald.

Thematically, this track bares some similarity and resemblance to ‘Lava Lamp’ and ‘Jethro’ which revolve around the concept of death, loss and the daunting inevitability of mortality. Thundercat really expresses his fears and difficulties to accept and embrace these natural thoughts and concerns.

Thundercat instructs us to make the most out of the life that we have been gifted and that mortality is nothing to fear, emphasizing some form of life after death that should be embraced and not feared. Similar to ‘Dweller on the Threshold’, Thundercat describes some kind of abstract location that exists on the precipice of life itself, almost in an alternate dimension or an out of body experience.

The track is an expression of love and light that finds him trading verses with a pair of unexpected, yet completely logical co-conspirators: yacht rock maestros Kenny Loggins and Michael McDonald.

Thematically, this track bares some similarity and resemblance to ‘Lava Lamp’ and ‘Jethro’ which revolve around the concept of death, loss and the daunting inevitability of mortality. Thundercat really expresses his fears and difficulties to accept and embrace these natural thoughts and concerns.

Thundercat instructs us to make the most out of the life that we have been gifted and that mortality is nothing to fear, emphasizing some form of life after death that should be embraced and not feared. description.plain:
As the three artists collaborate with one another officially for the first time on the song “Fair Chance,” Thundercat, Ty Dolla $ign and Lil B pay tribute to their common late friend and fellow artist Mac Miller, who passed away in September 2018 due to a drug overdose.

On a minimal and dreamy instrumental, produced by Thundercat himself together with Sounwave and Flying Lotus, the artists involved all deal with the heartbreaking effects stemming from the loss of Miller, with Ty Dolla $ign notably interpolating three different songs from the Pittsburgh native’s 2018 album Swimming, released just months before his tragic death.

In January 2020, Thundercat told Zane Lowe how the artistic and emotional impact Mac left on him poured over It Is What It Is:

The moments that me and that man shared when it came to the creative energy and stuff like that, I’m happy that I got a chance to experience somebody encompassing like that, because everything does tend to isolate you in certain respects. It’s like, you go too far off into one world, you tend to become biased. […] I was changed forever [by my experience with the loss of Mac], even if I didn’t want to, it just changed me: that’s just one example of the thing of It Is What It Is.

songs.embed_content: Read “Fair Chance” by Thundercat on Genius

description.plain:
A sequel to Thundercat’s previous cat-based anthem “Tron Song”, this track touches on the beauty of the feline life.

“Tron” is the shorthand name of Thundercat’s cat, whose real name is a lot more complicated:

https://twitter.com/thundercat/status/643847026430623744

description.plain:
The second song from Thundercat’s third studio album Drunk depicts himself in a state of monotony. The lyrics and the song itself seem to go in circles symbolizing every day of his life, filled with pointless routines.

This song is the first one to welcome us into the “Rabbit Hole” Thundercat is traveling to on the intro to the album.

songs.embed_content: Read “Captain Stupido” by Thundercat on Genius
songs.title: Captain Stupido

body.plain:
The second song from Thundercat’s third studio album Drunk depicts himself in a state of monotony. The lyrics and the song itself seem to go in circles symbolizing every day of his life, filled with pointless routines.

This song is the first one to welcome us into the “Rabbit Hole” Thundercat is traveling to on the intro to the album.

description.plain:
“Tokyo” is an ode to the capital of Japan. The song is about many things you can do in Tokyo, and Japan in general. It includes many cultural references and activities such as anime, pachinko, and the infamous suicide forest.

The fast paced nature of the song’s beat and the lyrical delivery might reference how overwhelming and large the city is, or also referring to how Tokyo was all a rush as he might have been drunk in Japan, like the album name suggests.

songs.embed_content: Read “Tokyo” by Thundercat on Genius
songs.title: Tokyo

description.plain: “Black Qualls” is a mellow funky cut with a positive message about overcoming paranoia, and no longer living in fear.  The initial version of this track was released without Childish Gambino’s verse. However, the album version of this track has a third verse on which Gambino singing about societies obsession with technology.

description.plain:
“Lava Lamp” finds Thundercat musing on death. It seems he’s set on chasing somebody who’s gone before him, perhaps his late friend and fellow Brainfeeder musician Austin Peralta, who sadly passed away in 2012. He finishes the song by finding a silver lining – maybe “in another life” he’ll see them again.

The themes of death continue into the next track, “Jethro.”

description.plain:
This song is a touching ode from Thundercat to his beloved pet cat Turbo Tron Over 9000 Baby Jesus Sally.

On a brief twitter commentary of each track on Thundercat’s second album Apocalypse, producer Flying Lotus tweeted:

tron song… this is one of the ones i was most involved in. we started this from scratch together. thunders lil girl suggested we write a song about their cat.. so we did

Released on September 10, 2014, the $5k-budget music video for this song, directed by comedian Eric Andre, is known for its bizarre visuals, over-the-top humor, and cheap throwback special effects. It is part of comedy collective JASH’s “$5k Music Videos” series where they give $5000 to a musician and a comedian to direct a music video.

songs.embed_content: Read “Tron Song” by Thundercat on Genius
songs.title: Tron Song

description.plain:
Based on a motif from Foster Sylvers' Misdemeanor, the song is a reflection on heartbreak and longing.



Via Flying Lotus’s Twitter commentary  about “Heartbreaks + Setbacks”:

heartbreaksetbacks..was mostly an instrumental that @mono__poly started and thunder got into.. the inst alone was so good i was scared 4 vox. when he says ‘CAINT LET THIS LOVE STOP" reminds me of MJ and makes me teary every time i hear it for so many reasons. we didn’t use no pitch correction at all on this album.. I’m so proud of that.. and him.

songs.embed_content: Read “Heartbreaks + Setbacks” by Thundercat on Genius

description.plain:
“Jethro” continues the death-oriented philosophising of “Lava Lamp,” albeit over a more energetic instrumental.

In “Lava Lamp,” his preoccupation with death was directed at somebody he missed, whilst “Jethro” seems to be a more abstract look at the idea.

description.plain:
“The Turn Down” is the first official collaboration between Thundercat and Pharrell Williams, though both artists contributed backing vocals to Kendrick Lamar’s 2015 single, “Alright.”

“The Turn Down” is a politically minded song in which the pair explore pollution, racism, brainwashing and the Black Lives Matter movement.

body.plain:
“The Turn Down” is the first official collaboration between Thundercat and Pharrell Williams, though both artists contributed backing vocals to Kendrick Lamar’s 2015 single, “Alright.”

“The Turn Down” is a politically minded song in which the pair explore pollution, racism, brainwashing and the Black Lives Matter movement.

description.plain:
“Rabbot Ho” is the opening to Drunk, a 40-second introduction to the album. Thundercat, feeling “kind of bored,” decides to “get drunk and travel down a rabbit hole” – a “rabbit hole” down which we descend throughout the album.

“Rabbot Ho” is musically and lyrically similar to album-closer “DUI” – so much so, in fact, that the album is effectively circular.

songs.embed_content: Read “Rabbot Ho” by Thundercat on Genius
songs.title: Rabbot Ho

“Rabbot Ho” is musically and lyrically similar to album-closer “DUI” – so much so, in fact, that the album is effectively circular.

description.plain:
“Unrequited Love” is a song on the 2019 anime series Carole & Tuesday from the character Skip, performed by Thundercat in the Cydonia Festival in episode 6.

Skip reveals that the song is about Crystal, another popular singer in the anime. The theme is really melancholic because it’s about not being over someone you love.

description.plain:
“Drink Dat” is the second collaboration between Thundercat and rapper Wiz Khalifa, the pair having previously linked up on Wiz’s 2014 track “Something Special.”

This collaboration finds the pair partying hard, egged on by a girl who continually wants to get higher and higher. Even though he’s “too faded” when he’s “up past the clouds,” the girl tells Thundercat to “come to outer space” with her.

body.plain:
“Drink Dat” is the second collaboration between Thundercat and rapper Wiz Khalifa, the pair having previously linked up on Wiz’s 2014 track “Something Special.”

This collaboration finds the pair partying hard, egged on by a girl who continually wants to get higher and higher. Even though he’s “too faded” when he’s “up past the clouds,” the girl tells Thundercat to “come to outer space” with her.

description.plain:
Infused with BADBADNOTGOOD’s magic, this song was the brainchild of Flying Lotus’s long-awaited attempt to get them and Thundercat to work together.

“King of the Hill” takes It Is What It Is on a philosophical turn, asking the question: How would life be different if we focused more on the important things?

description.plain: “Uh Uh” is a two-minute instrumental track towards the top of Thundercat’s 2017 album Drunk. After only 20 seconds of an atmospheric intro, the listener suddenly finds him flying through a furious bass solo at 158 BPM with Dennis Hamm following right behind on piano. They show off their brilliant musicianship over a stressed-out sample of the classic breakbeat from “Ashley’s Roachclip” by The Soul Searchers.

songs.embed_content: Read “Uh Uh” by Thundercat on Genius
songs.title: Uh Uh

description.plain:
“Jameel’s Space Ride” is a 71 second song named after Thundercat’s younger brother Jameel Bruner. Jameel is also a Grammy-nominated musician, but has confirmed via his official Twitter account that he played no role in the creation of the song.

https://twitter.com/Yagatomo98/status/835393002373853186

https://twitter.com/Pejondis/status/835686266830139392

description.plain: With “Interstellar Love”, Thundercat takes us on a jazz-infused sonic journey through the cosmos. Recognizing, through his lyrics, he and his companion’s decaying human forms, Thundercat creates a tone of ephemeral joy. Through the near orgasmic instrumentation that follows, led by Kamasi Washington’s sax, Thundercat paints an exciting picture of the two taking advantage of the fleeting moments [insert imagination here].

songs.title: Innerstellar Love

description.plain:
Thundercat attempts to convince the listener(and probably also homself) to simply “dance” through their pain, with the promise that things will work out if they just keep dancing.

Possibly a commentary on how often people are advised to work through/ignore their emotional problems/depression with a false image of joy

description.plain:
“DUI” utilises the same melody as album opener “Rabbot Ho,” making for a kind of circular record.

The song also uses imagery from throughout the album – the titular drunkenness is alluded to, whilst images of death, prominent in tracks such as “Lava Lamp” and “Jethro,” are also invoked.

description.plain:
Via Flying Lotus’s Twitter commentary  about “Evangelion”:

evangelion – i said when everyone listens to the big tunes over and over.. this will be the one they smoke to [and] trip to. its a secret favorite. i tried to record this and make it sound all classic psych. its funny.. this song sounds like tape too but its not. go ableton.

The song is named after an anime series called Neon Genesis Evangelion.

description.plain:
Via Flying Lotus’s Twitter commentary  about “Tenfold”:

tenfold was one of the first things that we considered for the new album. always knew it would be track 1. the sentiment feels like ‘I’m back.’ i love that lil bridge part.. my fav part of the song.. wanted to make it feel like dragon ball z. he looked at me like i was crazy when i played him the distorted guitar version hahaha i think he learned to love it.

description.plain:
Via Flying Lotus’s Twitter commentary:

u wanna see some sad shit.. see us try to record this song about @AustinPeralta … he would try to record. then he would cry.. then he would be stronger i would hear him sing this acapella because he had headphones on. id cry … hearing him try to fight thru crying to sing this.. damn. … so.. we gave up … we said… fuck it.. make the demo vocals sound as good as possible. i couldn’t finish it so i passed this song to @daddykev to mix the vox. i remember playing this for @strangelooptv and when i heard him cry i knew we did the right thing. i was also worried that nobody would get it but people who knew us or knew austin. so many people have told me its their favorite [though]. thats how i knew it would be impossible for @Thundercatbass to fail.

songs.embed_content: Read “A Message for Austin / Praise the Lord / Enter the Void” by Thundercat on Genius

description.plain:
Thundercat welcomes us to the album with this tone-setting intro. He does not hesitate to let us know where his mental space is at

Somewhere lost in space.

Not only are listeners coming into their awareness of the album with this intro, but we are hearing Thundercat come into awareness of himself as well as the fact that he’s not alone. Who’s with him? Maybe another manifestation of himself, maybe his fallen homies (i.e. Mac Miller), maybe the listener him/herself. Either way the show will go on.

description.plain:
The title is a reference to Kanye West’s 2013 interview on Sway in the Morning:

https://youtu.be/S78tT_YxF_c?t=1042

Described by Flying Lotus himself to be a “crazy little burst of insanity”, this song is a purely instrumental, energy-filled jazz explosion with an off-kilter feel that’s just sublime.

description.plain:
If there was ever a song to encapsulate the collective dread and combined yearning for optimism that has come with the year 2020, then it’s this one.

“Existential Dread” is a simple affirmation of the troubling thoughts that enter our minds and a reminder to just let them go when they come.

The song truly is almost like a meditation, complete with a focus on breathing, and a repetition of the mantra:

I know I’ll be alright"

songs.embed_content: Read “Existential Dread” by Thundercat on Genius
songs.title: Existential Dread

description.plain:
This song is a reference to the classic manga series “Lone Wolf & Cub”, which was turned into a TV series and a cult-classic film “Shogun Assassin”.

The series tells the story of a former executioner for a Japanese Shogun, Ogami Itto (Lone Wolf). As the Shogun grows old, he becomes more paranoid of those under his command and orders the killings of those he views as disloyal. He sends ninja spies to Lone Wolf’s house to kill him, but instead they kill his wife. From then, he takes his son, Daigoro (the Cub) on his bloody quest for revenge.

Thundercat has also stated on his Twitter that his song is also for the “Lone Wolves in real life”, the single parents who will do anything to care for and protect their children, much like Ogami Itto.

The series tells the story of a former executioner for a Japanese Shogun, Ogami Itto (Lone Wolf). As the Shogun grows old, he becomes more paranoid of those under his command and orders the killings of those he views as disloyal. He sends ninja spies to Lone Wolf’s house to kill him, but instead they kill his wife. From then, he takes his son, Daigoro (the Cub) on his bloody quest for revenge.

description.plain:
“Hi” is a bonus track included on Japanese versions of Drunk. It features Mac Miller, with whom Thundercat has collaborated before: he provided vocals to Miller’s “In The Morning” and produced tracks “Break The Law” and “Brand Name.”

It’s unsurprising that Japan should get such a special collaboration as a bonus – Thundercat’s very open about his love of Japan, from the aesthetic of his 2015 LP The Beyond / Where The Giant’s Roam to the samurai-featuring music video for his song “Them Changes” and his Japanophilic Drunk cut, “Tokyo.”

songs.embed_content: Read “Hi” by Thundercat on Genius
songs.title: Hi

description.plain:
Via Flying Lotus’s Twitter commentary  about “Without You”:

‘without you’ i always laugh when this starts.. i always hoped that thunders sense of humor would come across with his album. i mixed this whole album. i learned a lot this time around. working wit thunder is a very unique and magical experience. its funny to see what people have to say about watching us work. if u haven’t all u producers should try recording on to tape one time.. just to hear what u get. i would do some shit differently next time. theres a lot of cowboy shit in this album in my opinion..

songs.embed_content: Read “Without You” by Thundercat on Genius
songs.title: Without You

description.plain: “Hard Times” serves as a short introduction to The Beyond/Where The Giants Roam, establishing one of the EP’s central themes: the experience of death and the afterlife. Here, we see the initial post-death reaction of the EP’s central protagonist as he contemplates the limbo he finds himself in. Thundercat’s quiet instrumentation and lofty, heavenly vocals promote the idea that the protagonist is alone and introspective.

description.plain: This song serves as a capstone to the concepts and realms explored so far in the EP (death, afterlife, limbo/bardo, consciousness, etc.). It explicitly states how our perceived physical reality only appears to be real, something echoed in previous tracks. It also references how within our minds lies the answer to everything, the inevitable unfurling fabric of existence.

body.plain: This song serves as a capstone to the concepts and realms explored so far in the EP (death, afterlife, limbo/bardo, consciousness, etc.). It explicitly states how our perceived physical reality only appears to be real, something echoed in previous tracks. It also references how within our minds lies the answer to everything, the inevitable unfurling fabric of existence.

description.plain: A song released as apart of the 2017/2018  Adult Swim Singles Free Music Promotion, Thundercat debuts his first single since the 2017, 22 track long album, “Drunk” which has several references to tracks on “Drunk”. As for the song’s story, it follows along the lines of Thundercat in a somewhat dangerous, yet enjoyable relationship with a woman, as she punches in her sleep, takes forever to get ready, and eventually drives him to jump out the window to free himself, and gain the freedom to go up, and down the rabbit hole.

songs.embed_content: Read “Final Fight” by Thundercat on Genius
songs.title: Final Fight

body.plain: A song released as apart of the 2017/2018  Adult Swim Singles Free Music Promotion, Thundercat debuts his first single since the 2017, 22 track long album, “Drunk” which has several references to tracks on “Drunk”. As for the song’s story, it follows along the lines of Thundercat in a somewhat dangerous, yet enjoyable relationship with a woman, as she punches in her sleep, takes forever to get ready, and eventually drives him to jump out the window to free himself, and gain the freedom to go up, and down the rabbit hole.

description.plain:
Via Flying Lotus’s Twitter commentary  about “Seven”:

Seven.we tried to make this #7 but it didn’t work out. that would have been tight.. but its actually in 7 so it works. thunder and @ZackSekoff. there were a few versions of this but i liked the super simplified one.. this always reminds me of mortal kombat.. eyes open wide burning bright as light.. we were trying to be on some ‘gentle giant’ shit after @nikalotta challenged us.

songs.embed_content: Read “Seven” by Thundercat on Genius
songs.title: Seven

description.plain:
Via Flying Lotus’s Twitter commentary  about “The Life Aquatic”:

life aquatic.. we used to call this ‘the steve zisou (fucked spelling) beat’ thunder and taylor graves made this the same day as tenfold. some underwater odyssey shit.
